messageBody:
Hi,

I have tried spreadsheet example in several TDD courses and actually
it didn't worked out so well. Spreadsheet application was a starting
point and then we moved into a complicated J2EE example.

The problem in this course setup is the amount of material
participants have to swallow and tolerate and little technical details
that are coming into the game. Most of the people coming into theses
courses are not some J2EE or Struts gurus, which can easily work with
any setup you offer in the course. They do some changes now and then
and some others are taking care of the rest. Environmental details
shouldn't block them from seeing the TDD benefits. They may even think
later on that the course was all about the testing environment setup
or something really technical, but that shouldn't be the case!

I'm suggesting that TDD courses should stick with the simple examples
like spreadsheet. This way the actual TDD idea is visible all the time
and not the technical details.

One problem still is that most professional programmers don't want to
spend time with trivial things like spreadsheet applications, if they
don't see some fundamental reasons for doing it. They want to see how
all happends in their build environment and with same size projects
that they deal with.

This means that you have to sell the idea with concrete examples and
experiences, before doing anything.

Teppo
